data.title: Something missing.
data.text: The Museum provides good information about coming to America.   However, it does not provide sufficient information as to what the people's lives were like prior to coming.   There was no sequence to the information presented and it was disjointed.   I understand this is an ongoing story but I think it fails in many ways.   I sincerely hope they expand the depth of info and become even more successful.

data.title: worthwhile visit to a small museum
data.text: Really enjoyed the displays and quiet in this small museum highlighting Arab history, religion, culture, food, etc.  Lots of good information in a beautiful setting.  I wish they had had some information on  9/11 and events thereafter which showed Arab support for the US.  The exhibit of "What we carried" (might not be correct title) was very poignant and showed the plight of recent immigrants from the Middle East.  Very worthwhile few hours.

data.title: Great way to learn about Islam and the Middle East
data.text: I am so glad I finally made time to visit! As a non-Arab, I have always been curious about Islam and the Middle East, and this museum is perfect place to gain an understanding of those questions. I recommend following the phone-guided tour at your own pace. The staff was very friendly and helpful with my questions after my visit too.

data.title: Great History of Arab Americans in Crucial Time
data.text: The museum is well done to reflect the heritage of Arab Americans in America from the 19th century and beyond.  Great interactive exhibit. Stop by the store for beautiful artifacts.  It is a must for every visitor to Dearborn. It is the only and the first Arab American History museum in the country.

data.title: Went as chaperone with high school girls
data.text: Guide was not the best. Still, take a guided tour, then just walk around as you wish to fill in some the blanks. Very informative and enlightening. Most displays have succinct, written explanations designed as a quick read for a group with mixed interests. Found out some things I did not know. Someone interested in history or the Arab world in general may enjoy this.

data.title: Much needed Arab American National Museum
data.text: This place is a great place to visit and very well done.  Gives you an insight to the contributions that American Arabs have made that have benefited the USA.  In this day and age where very little is known about our sister, brothers and friends from the Arab region.  A place like this provides a lot of information for people that have little knowledge on the subject of the middle east or the people that reside there, and its people that have immigrated to the USA.

data.title: Waste of time
data.text: Not a good experience at all, not very user friendly at all,  Poor treatment towards us, n o t welcoming at all.

data.title: Beautiful History
data.text: Great museum with lots of history. As an Arab-Canadian it was neat to learn about the contributions of Arabs in America, I hope to see future displays about Arab-Canadians. Friendly staff and beautiful gift shop.

data.title: Learning Other Cultures
data.text: It shows how a Culture arrived in America and Progressed.   Very informative.    Well done .  Smaller Museum but self guided.

data.title: A stunningly beautiful exhibit
data.text: A wonderful place for those outside of our area to come and see the history and experience a touch of the Arab culture that makes our city so grand

data.title: Worth a Visit
data.text:
Did you know there were over 150 Arabs on the Titanic? (Plus Armenians, Turks and others? Unmentioned, but also true.) As a amateur Arabic history buff, I wanted to like this place more, and an Arab, Arab-American or possibly Muslim generally might rate this attraction higher, but I think the average person would rate it similarly to what I have.   

Positives: Beautiful restored building with very nice facilities; generally the displays are well lit,well labelled, accurate and instructional; 3 full floors of displays, wonderful lecture hall seating 150; some Arabic architectural features; covers broad range of Arab and Arab-American contributions to culture; some good video and oral historical material; there is a library and a gift shop

Negatives: Mostly static displays; mostly superficial treatment; mostly fails to address the complexity/range of Arabic culture ( as far as I could tell there was no mention of the individual Muslim and Christian communities of the Middle East: Sunni, Shia, Maronite, Melkite, Antiochan Orthodox, Druze, etc.). Did I miss mention of major Arabic organizations? e.g. ACCESS, ADC How about Mikhail Naimy? Minor display of Kahlil Gibran---a major figure

data.title: Snoozville
data.text:
As an Arab American I was excited to visit this museum from Chicago. Unfortunately it's pretty basic and pretty boring. Didn't learn anything I didn't know already, except maybe some local history as to the first Arabs that settled in Dearborn. 

This may be a cooler experience if you don't know much about the Arab culture.

data.title: Over rated
data.text: If you are Muslim it probably is worth seeing.  If not, I doubt it would be interesting to you.  Good propaganda.  Reasonably good dialogue.

data.title: A great learning experience!
data.text: Learned a lot here about the contributions of Arab-Americans and about historical contributions in the fields of engineering, medicine and architecture. The museum is very visually pleasing, nice music playing throughout our visit.

data.title: Learned More Than We Thought
data.text:
What an absolute delight to visit here! From the roots of the Arab ethnicity, to the modern day contributions of Arab Americans to this country, this museum houses so much rich education for ANY person.

It's one thing to learn about the journey your parents took to get to America, and it's another to read through the tales of other Arabs that came before them. Learning about the many Arabs living and thriving when America was still building just left me in awe. Every corner of this building is just beautiful. There are a few interactive exhibits that were fun, too.

I visited with a relative that was actually visiting from the Middle East. Long story short, we left more proud of our people.

data.title: Fun and mind-opening!
data.text:
If you were to go and explore the museum alone, you'd be taken aback by the beauty of the displays and architecture. The displays are very informative, and sometimes they have a section dedicated to art created by Arabs or Arab-Americans. The museum presents many aspects of the Arab identity, such as religion, stereotypes, definition of what an Arab is, an Arab-American history, etc. 

My recommendation: BOOK A TOUR GUIDE. I went with a group with school mates interested in learning about the Arab-American perspective. We requested a tour of about an hour. We were guided by two incredibly intelligent, patient, organized, and friendly women. They always responded thoughtfully and in detail to our questions. There was so much information; it was impossible to learn everything in the museum given the time we requested. However, our tour guides focused on the topics we were interested in and told us everything they knew. It was because of them that I felt I was able to learn as much as I did. I loved the trip. It was mind-opening, informative, and lots of fun. I recommend visiting this place to everyone (couples, family, young kids, teenagers, adults, etc.) If it's your first time and you want a tour guide, request an hour to be safe. Bring friends! It's fun to learn with others. (:

Also, if you're a student, bring a student ID! There's a discount.

data.title: A gem of a museum
data.text: I hope more people take the time to discover this wonderful museum.  The displays were entertaining and very informative.  I loved the interactive technology.  Staff was friendly and took the time to answer all of our questions.  I plan to come back and would highly recommend this museum

data.title: Informative and nicely put together.
data.text: Went with a school group and it was a nice museum, just on the smaller side, so it won't take you more than an hour or two to complete.  Location is near plenty of good restaurants, so make a nice afternoon of it.

data.title: Impressive
data.text: We were impressed with how spacious and beautiful the building is. I enjoyed how inactive it was and the art displays. The receptionist was very helpful and pleasant. The first floor has a magnificent view of the dome. You can use your cell phone to call the museum and then type in the number located on the display you are interested in and it will give a short description. That was helpful to me. Of course, some of the info was rather biased, but I would expect that in any museum dedicated to celebrating one specific topic.

data.title: Educational and Excellent
data.text:
My last day in the Detroit area and on my way to Detroit Metro Airport from Downtown. This museum I almost passed and didn't see but I was glad I did. 

Please take the time as its $8.00 well spent as this museums size is misleading as there are 3 floors of art, history and sites.
